title-group.article-title: Locomotion Selectively Amplifies Sensitizing Neurons in Primary Visual Cortex

abstract.p: Sensory processing in the cortex is shaped both by adaptation to external stimuli and by changes in internal state but it is not known how these processes interact, in large part because neuromodulatory changes in synaptic strength are difficult to quantify in behaving animals. Here we combine two-photon calcium imaging, optogenetics and circuit modelling to investigate how locomotion adjusts adaptation in layer 2/3 of mouse primary visual cortex (V1). We show that this change in state preferentially increases gain in PCs that sensitize during a high-contrast visual stimulus, while having weaker effects on PCs that depress. A population model constrained by a number of optogenetic manipulations accounts for the differential modulation of PCs during locomotion on the basis of i) variations in the connections that individual PCs receive from PV and SST interneurons, ii) a broad weakening of PC and PV synapses to all local targets, and iii) enhanced inhibition from SST synapses targetting depressing PCs. These results provide a quantitative and integrated understanding of how state-dependent modulation of cortical circuits can selectively bias cortical computation toward different adaptive regimes. The apparently paradoxical combination of increased PC gain but decreased synaptic strength suggests a state-dependent gating mechanism that boosts signals leaving V1 for higher visual areas while simultaneously preventing disruption of the excitatory-inhibitory balance required for stable local computation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sensory processing in the cortex is adjusted both by adaptation to the external environment and changes in the internal physiology of the animal that generate behavioural states such as attention, arousal and satiety1–5. The mechanisms by which external and internal variables interact within the cortical circuitry are not understood. Here we investigate this question by analyzing how the change in state associated with locomotor activity impacts adaptation in primary visual cortex (V1) of mice6.

The dynamics of neurons in V1 reflect adaptation on multiple time-scales. In pyramidal cells (PCs), the initial excitatory response to an increase in contrast is followed by a fast (subsecond) decrease in gain reflecting depression in feedforward inputs from the LGN7,8. This is immediately followed by a slower phase of adaptation that varies dramatically across the PC population: while some PCs depress in response to a high-contrast stimulus others simultaneously sensitize9. PCs within layer 2/3 are not, therefore, a homogenous population: to understand gain control we must take into account variations in local inhibitory circuits in which they are embedded.

The onset of locomotion signals changes in internal state associated with attention or arousal, acting in less than a second to amplify visual responses in PCs3,10–12. A major driver of this increase in gain are cholinergic fibers arriving from the basal forebrain2,13–15. A minority of fibers make direct synaptic connections that excite interneurons expressing vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP)16, leading to amplification of PC responses through a VIP->SST->PC disinhibitory pathway. The majority of the cholinergic input, however, innervates V1 diffusely to modulate circuit function through extra-synaptic (muscarinic) receptors2,13,16. In vitro experiments, have shown that M1 and M3 receptors on soma and dendrites of PCs can increase excitability while M2 receptors on axonal compartments reduce synaptic release probability16–18. Accounting for state-dependent changes in cortical processing therefore requires an integrated understanding of changes in both electrical activity and the strength of synaptic connections12. The difficulty, however, is that modulations of synaptic strengths are very hard to quantify in awake and behaving animals: recording from connected neuron pairs remains technically challenging and is limited to anaesthetized animals in which inhibitory microcircuits are severely compromised 19–21. Current knowledge about synaptic modulation in cortical circuits is derived from ex vivo studies or inferred from indirect in vivo observations and modelling 12,22.

To understand how locomotion and adaptation interact in V1 of mice we used calcium imaging to record visual responses in PCs and the three major classes of interneuron (VIP, SST and PV), optogenetics to identify key interactions and a data-driven circuit model to estimate changes in synaptic weights. We demonstrate that long-range inputs to VIPs that increase visual gain in the locomoting state also govern the time-course of adaptation over the behavioural time-scales of seconds. These inputs do not act uniformly across the PC population but preferentially increases the gain of sensitizing neurons. Contrary to the prevailing model of gain control through the VIP->SST->PC pathway we find that visual responses in SSTs are not inhibited by locomotion but instead weakly enhanced. These observations can be reconciled by also taking into account neuromodulatory changes in synaptic strength, and our results predict a decrease in the strength of connections from PCs to all their targets and an increase in the strength of inhibitory connections made by SSTs. Locomotion preferentially increases the gain of PCs that undergo the sensitizing form of adaptation because these are at least seven times more strongly connected to SSTs compared to PVs. These results provide an integrated view of the circuit mechanisms which cause locomotion-dependent changes in gain to interact with adaptation to adjust visual processing in V1.

sec.title: Differential effects of locomotion on the fast and slow phases of adaptation
sec.p: To understand how changes in brain state interact with adaptation in V1 we used two-photon calcium imaging to measure the activity of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in layer 2/3 during periods of rest and locomotion (Fig 1A, see Methods). The GCaMP6f signal in PCs responding to a high contrast stimulus (20° drifting grating at 1 Hz, 10 s duration) are shown in Fig. 1B. Locomotion increased the response averaged across all PCs by a factor of 2.2 ± 0.9. The dynamics of individual neurons, however, varied widely: some PCs responded with high initial gain and then depressed, while others responded with low initial gain and then sensitized. This heterogeneity is illustrated by the raster plot in Fig. 1B which shows 522 neurons ordered by the time of peak activity: depression (early peak) and sensitization (late peak) were similarly represented in the two behavioural states (Fig 1B, top).

The increase in gain during locomotion was manifested in two ways; a 6-fold increase in the number of PCs generating a significant response (Table 1) and an increase in the average amplitude of these responses measured as the integral during the 10 s stimulus (Fig. 1B). To investigate how these changes in gain affected PCs undergoing different forms of adaptation we split the population into three groups of equal size based on the distribution of a metric called the adaptive index (AI; Methods). These groups were sensitizing (AI less than zero), intermediate and depressing (AI more than zero; Fig. 1C). The AI averaged across the whole PC population was similar during locomotion (-0.006 ± 0.3; mean ± sem) and rest (0.001 ± 0.9; Fig. 1C) but the amplitude of the visual response increased by a factor of 4.5 ± 0.7 in sensitizing PCs, 2.5 ± 0.3 in intermediate group and 2.2 ± 0.2 in depressors. Locomotion therefore increased the gain of sensitizing PCs about twice as strongly as depressors (Fig. 1D-G).

The immediate spiking response to a high-contrast stimulus is dominated by depressing adaptation7,8 but the raw signal from calcium reporter proteins such as GCaMP does not easily distinguish this phase because of the gradual accumulation of calcium in the neuron. Several algorithms for estimating spike rates from calcium signals are now in use23–25 and we applied MLspike because it is based on a biological model of GCaMP activation and calcium dynamics that has been shown to perform better than others2626. The first component of the spiking response was followed by fast depressing adaptation, as expected from electrophysiology7,8,27 (red arrows In Fig. 2A-B). During locomotion, the initial peak amplitude was not significantly different in PCs that depressed (1.15 ± 0.08 Hz) or sensitized (1.11 ± 0.08 Hz), indicating similar actions of the feedforward input across the PC population (Fig. 2C).

Comparing activity at rest and while running revealed a powerful effect on both first and second phases of the response but this varied across the PC population. In the sensitizing tertile the initial peak driven by feedforward input underwent a relative change of 2.1 ± 0.7, calculated as (response locomoting – response at rest)/response at rest) and the response integrated over the whole stimulus a relative change of 4.7 ± 1 (Fig. 2D). But in the depressing tertile, locomotion did not significantly change the initial fast response while the integrated response only increased by a factor of 1.4 ± 0.3 (Fig. 2E). Changes in internal state associated with locomotion do not, therefore, act uniformly across the PC population but preferentially increase the gain of neurons that undergo the sensitizing form of adaptation.

sec.title: A data-driven model of contrast adaptation and the effects of locomotion
sec.p: To understand how locomotion preferentially modulates PCs undergoing the sensitizing mode of adaptation we constructed a population model of signal flow based on neuronal input-output functions expressed as firing rates28–30 (see Methods). The aim was not to provide a comprehensive description of all the processes that might operate on the time-scales of the visual responses, such as different modes of synaptic plasticity: our aim was to understand key features that could explain the link between adaptative changes and the locomoting state shown in Fig. 2D and E. The model took into account three aspects of circuits in layer 2/3: i) the measured response dynamics of PCs (Fig. 2) and the three major types of interneurons (Fig. 3); ii) the dynamics of signals that arrive from other brain regions (Fig. 4A), and iii) the known connectivity patterns of neurons within this layer (Fig. 4B). Code and example data sets at https://github.com/laqnadoLab/CortexModel.

sec.title: i) The dynamics of neurons in layer 2/3
sec.p: A key determinant of the magnitude and direction of slow adaptive changes in a PC is the local inhibitory microcircuit in which it is embedded: PCs in which direct SST inputs dominate over PV inputs tend to sensitize while those in which PV inputs dominate depress9. We therefore also measured the effects of locomotion on gain and adaptation of the three major types of interneurons (Fig. 3). VIPs underwent the strongest modulation: the density of responsive neurons increased by a factor of 3 (Table 1), and the amplitude of these responses increased by factor of 5.1 ± 1.0 (Fig. 3A). Simultaneously, locomotion caused the ratio of sensitizing (AI <0) to depressing (AI > 0) VIPs to increase from 1.3 at rest to 9 (Fig. 3D). PVs were more weakly modulated, with a gain factor of 1.7 ± 0.2 while the ratio of sensitizers to depressors also increased from 1.8 to 6.1 (Fig. 3B and E). In contrast, locomotion did not significantly alter the number of responsive SST neurons or the amplitude of their responses (gain factor of 1.2 ± 0.2; p = 0.28; Fig. 3C and F). This observation was surprising given that VIPs powerfully inhibit SSTs and locomotion activates a VIP->SST->PC disinhibitory pathway proposed to be the major mechanism of gain control11,31,32. A major aim of the model, therefore, was to take a more integrated view of gain control that considered multiple interacting pathways within layer 2/3.

The distribution of response dynamics in interneurons was more homogenous than PCs. In PCs, the probabilities of a neuron being sensitizing (AI <0) or depressing (AI > 0) were both ~0.5 (Fig. 1C), but during locomotion sensitization dominated in VIPs and PVs (Psens = 0.9) while depression dominated in SSTs (Pdep = 0.8; Fig. 3D-F). We therefore used a population mean field model in which a single response dynamic, measured as the average shown in Fig. 3A-C, describes each type of interneuron. Mean field models have been widely used to describe the average behaviour of large populations of interacting neurons without simulating each neuron individually28,33, 34. The network was represented by a system of four first order ordinary differential equations28: (1)τidridt=−ri+f(∑jwjirj+winIn+bi) where i,j are iterating through the four neuronal populations (PC, VIP, PV and SST), j is a presynaptic population and i. postsynaptic, r is a firing rate and τi is the time-constant for that population. f(x) is a neuronal input-output function and here we used a rectified power low30. The connection weight between populations j and i, wji, is simply the product of the total number of synaptic connections, Cji, and the average strength of an individual synapse, sji: (2)wji=Cjisji
The total synaptic input that neuron i receives from j, Iji is proportional to the activity of j: (3)Iji=wjirj

To compare the model to experiments it was important to consider that not all presynaptic neurons are activated by the stimulus and, even if they are, they will not all activate the postsynaptic population because the connection probability, pji, is usually less than one. If, for instance, electrodes are placed on a PC and a nearby PV interneuron the probability of them being connected is only ~0.37 at distances less than ~150 μm while the average probability of an SST interneuron is even lower at ~0.2735–37. These factors can be taken into account by expanding relation 2 as (4)wji=Njpjisji where Nj, is the number of responsive presynaptic cells, defined as described in Methods. Below we compare measured changes in Nj, caused by locomotion (Table 1) to changes in wji estimated by fitting the model, allowing us to estimate changes in the strength of individual synapses based on the reasonable assumption that connection probabilities are constant on the time-scale of minutes.

sec.title: ii) The dynamics of signals entering layer 2/3
sec.p: Excitatory signals entering layer 2/3 are of three main types38,39: feedforward (FF) drive originating from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and transmitted via layer 4, feedback from higher order cortices (FB)40,41 and modulatory inputs (SM), such as cholinergic signals from the basal nuclei11. Electrophysiology has shown that FF inputs to layer 2/3 are dominated by fast depressing adaptation occurring within a few hundred milliseconds and the fast phase of adaptation in PCs fell within this range7,8. (Fig. 2A-B). Calcium imaging in vivo has shown that drifting gratings lasting seconds can also generate a slower sensitizing component in FF inputs that enter layer 2/3 from layer 422,42. The FF input was therefore modelled with both these components, as shown in Fig. 4A.

The second type of input to V1 is feedback from higher visual areas43–45 and SST interneurons are a major target for these44,46,47. We have limited understanding of the dynamics of the FB signal over the time-scale of our stimulus, so, for simplicity, it was modelled as a step beginning at a delay of 380 ms after stimulus onset (Fig. 4A).

The third type of inputs to layer 2/3 are visually-activated signals that are strongly sensitizing in the locomoting state and drive slow modulation. This input was based on the response of VIPs during locomotion, for three reasons. First, cholinergic inputs from the basal forebrain are known to powerfully activate VIPs during locomotion11,48. Second, we could reliably measure the dynamics of this input to layer 2/3 because the visual stimulus only weakly activated VIPs at rest but much more strongly during locomotion (Fig. 3A). Third, and crucially, optogenetic experiments confirmed that activity in VIPs drove adaptation in downstream SST neurons (Fig. 4C-D). To carry out this test we had to express the inhibitory photoprotein ArchT in VIPs and GCaMP6f in SSTs. Expressing different proteins in two interneuron populations was achieved by crossing a recombinant mouse line expressing Cre (VIP-Cre) with a Flippase expressing line (SST-Flp), then injecting two viral vectors that were Cre and Flippase dependent respectively (see Methods). Suppressing activity in VIPs almost completely abolished the slow component of adaptation in SSTs (Fig. 4D), to which they are known to connect strongly11,31,32. Visually-driven inputs to VIPs include local recurrent excitation27 and inputs from higher visual areas41, and their combined dynamics were modelled on the VIP response (Fig. 4E).

Notably, the dynamics of sensitization in VIPs were also similar to sensitization in PCs suggesting that this input dominated the dynamics of slow adaptation throughout the network (Supplementary Figure 1).

sec.title: iii) Connectivity within layer 2/3
sec.p: Cortical connections have been probed using a number of approaches, including viral tracing52, electrophysiology31,35,37 and optogenetics36, and we only considered connections that have been consistently observed in layer 2/3 and are strong enough to significantly influence the circuit (Fig. 4B). Not all neuron types connect; SST interneurons, for example, do not interact with each other while the very small number of connections from VIPs to PCs were neglected because these are not strong enough to significantly influence the circuit31,36.

sec.title: Fine-tuning the model using optogenetics
sec.p: The model was fit to average populational responses of PCs and interneurons by adjusting the weights wij of external and internal connections in layer 2/3 (see Methods for approach to fitting). In some cases, different sets of weights were capable of fitting the four neuronal populations similarly well. The model was therefore constrained further using additional datasets consisting of average PC responses measured during a series of optogenetic perturbations (Fig. 5). First, we expressed the excitatory photoprotein ChrimsonR in SSTs and GCaMP6f in PCs by using a Cre-dependent viral vector in SST-Cre mouse line and GCaMP6f in PCs under the CaMKII promoter. The intensity of the photo-activating light was adjusted to increase the activity of SST interneurons by an average factor of ~1.4 in locomoting animals, as estimated in a separate series of experiments9. Fig. 5A (top) shows how the average PC response was reduced compared to interleaved control trials; scaling the average SST activity within the model by a factor of 1.4 while leaving all other parameters constant provided an accurate description of the change in average

Reducing the activity of SSTs by an average factor of about ~2 using ArchT had the opposite effect - amplification of the average PC response - and this action was also quantitatively captured by the model (Fig. 5A, bottom). Similar manipulations of activity were carried out in PV interneurons (Fig. 5B) and again the model could describe changes in PC activity, further narrowing the set of weights describing activity in layer 2/3. These results demonstrate that the model incorporates enough features to accurately account for the visual responses of all the major neuronal classes across a range of conditions.

sec.title: Locomotion increases PC gain but weakens their local synaptic output
sec.p: First, we investigated the action of locomotion averaged across the whole PC population (Fig. 6) and then explored why the subsets of PCs that sensitize are modulated more strongly than those that depress (Fig. 7).

The fits of the model to the average visual responses in the four cell types closely followed both the fast and slow phases of adaptation at rest and during locomotion (Fig. 6A-D). The total connection weights at rest are shown in the heatmaps in Fig. 6E and the relative changes are summarized in Fig. 6F, calculated as (5)[Wij(loco)−Wij(rest)]/Wij(rest) Where free parameters predicted by the model could be compared with published experiment, there were several points of agreement. For instance, variations in the strength of direct connections to PCs were quantitatively similar to those measured using electrophysiology35,36. The model also predicted the locomotion-dependent amplification of the slowly modulated input to both VIPs11 and PCs51 and stronger feedforward drive to PCs53,54.

Behavioural modulation of connection weights within layer 2/3 have been very hard to quantify experimentally, making it unclear how far changes in internal state adjust cortical processing through changes in neuronal activity as opposed to modulation of synaptic strength14,16. The model indicates that locomotion increases the gain of PCs through a broad combination of circuit effects but of particular importance is an approximate halving in the strength of inhibitory synapses made by PVs (Fig. 6G). This can be readily understood in terms of cholinergic modulation through M2 and M4 receptors that reduces release probability in PVs in visual55, somatosensory56 and auditory cortex57.

Strikingly, the model also predicts a 50-60% decrease in the total weight of connections from PCs to all types of interneurons following locomotion. Taking into account the 5-fold increase in the number of responsive PCs during locomotion (Table 1 and equation 4) this leads to an estimated 90% decrease in synaptic strength across all PC targets (Fig. 6G). Experiments in vitro again suggest a mechanism – activation of M2 receptors on presynaptic compartments reducing release probability16–18: The insight here is that the large increase in PC and PV activity during locomotion is associated with a wide-spread decrease in the strength of their local synapses. This might represent a mechanism that allows large changes in the gain of signals leaving V1 for higher visual areas but without overexcitation of PC targets within the local circuit (see Discussion).

In contrast, the effects of locomotion were accounted for by an increase in the average weight of SST connections to all their targets (Fig. 6F) consistent with the observation that cholinergic projections facilitate SSTs through both nicotinic and muscarinic receptors in31,58,59. The number of responsive SSTs neurons increased by only 22% (Table 1) indicating that the major cause was a strengthening of SST synapses (Fig. 6G). Experiments in vitro have shown that ACh strongly enhances SST → PC inhibition via M1 receptor-mediated potentiation of GABAA currents on PCs58,59.

Another way to summarize the effects of locomotion is to consider the change in the total synaptic input as PCs respond to the visual stimulus, which is the change in the weight of a connection multiplied by the activity of the presynaptic neuron (table 1; equation 3; Fig. 6F). The last column in Fig. 6H shows this change, taking into account the input received from all connected populations averaged over the stimulus presentation. The order of strength of the net excitatory input driving the visual response is VIP>PC>PV>SST, consistent with the effects of locomotion shown in Figs. 2 and 3. Note again that locomotion caused SSTs to receive weak net excitation during the stimulus rather than inhibition expected based on the VIP->SST->PC disinhibitory model. The overarching picture is that locomotion adjusts the gain of visual responses by modulating both excitatory signals entering layer 2/3 and the strength of local synaptic connections12.

sec.title: Differential modulation of SST synapses onto sensitizing and depressing PCs
sec.p: Why do some PCs sensitize while others depress? Optogenetic manipulations of interneurons indicate that the direction and amplitude of slow adaptation reflects the balance between PV and SST inputs9. PVs sensitize (Fig. 3B), so PCs in which these inputs dominate tend to depress, while SSTs depress (Fig. 3C), causing PCs in which these inputs dominate to sensitize. To make these ideas quantitative, we fit the model separately to the sensitizing, intermediate and depressing PC subpopulations (Fig. 7A-C). At rest, all the external connections to PCs had similar weights irrespective of adaptive properties; the stand-out differences were in the local inhibitory connections (Fig. 7D). In qualitative agreement with the “balance model”, the direction of adaptation of a PC was dependent on the ratio of the PV and SST inputs, which increased progressively between the sensitizing, intermediate and depressing populations (1.62, 11.8 and ~84, respectively; Fig. 7D). Considered in terms of the total drive that PCs receive from each of these interneuron populations, the PV:SST input ratio was 6.2, 0.62, and 0.45 in sensitizing, intermediate and depressing PCs, respectively (Fig. 7G).

A notable feature emerges when locomotion-dependent changes in synaptic weights are calculated: while SST synapses to depressing PCs more than double in strength, the connections to the sensitizing and intermediate groups became weaker (Fig. 7F). SSTs are a heterogenous class of neuron and are known to target PCs in two distinct ways. The most numerous type, Martinotti cells, synapse on distal apical dendrites of PCs in layer 1 and show strong depressing adaptation similar to the population average in Fig. 3C46,60,61. We suggest, therefore, that Martinotti cells are the dominant type of SST connected to sensitizing PCs. In contrast, non-Martinotti cells target the soma and basal dendrites and show much weaker adaptation59,62, suggesting that these preferentially target depressing PCs.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Adaptation is a fundamental aspect of sensory processing across cortical areas but it has not been clear how it is adjusted by changes in behavioural state that modulate these circuits. Our results demonstrate that in layer 2/3 of mouse V1 locomotion preferentially amplifies responses in PCs that exhibit sensitizing adaptation over behavioural time-scales while exerting minimal effects on depressing PCs (Figs. 1 and 2). A combination of experiment and data-driven modelling indicates that this differential modulation of the PC population reflects two major variations in their local inhibitory circuits. First, sensitizing PCs receive proportionally stronger SST input relative to PV input (Fig. 7) making them more susceptible to the locomotion-driven increase in SST inhibitory strength (Fig. 6). Second, locomotion differentially modulates synapses of SSTs, increasing the strength of connections to depressing PCs but weakening synapses to sensitizing PCs (Fig. 7). More generally, these results build from the simple model of gain control through the VIP→SST→PC disinhibition pathway 11,63 by also considering the broader neuromodulatory actions of the cholinergic input to V1 through a model. The results indicate that locomotion increases the gain of PCs through a combination of circuit effects, including a decrease in the strength of synapses mediating feedback inhibition from PV interneurons64 (Fig. 6 and 7).

sec.title: Gating the feedforward signal
sec.p: The increase in gain during locomotion was profound: the number of PCs responding to the stimulus increased by a factor of six (Table 1) and the average amplitude of those responses by a factor of 2-3 (Figs. 1 and 2). About 70–80% of PCs in layer 2/3 send axon collaterals to higher visual areas65,66 so these combined effects will strongly amplify the feedforward visual signal, at least to the drifting grating stimulus used here. The local recurrent signals are, however, strongly damped by a wide-spread decrease in the strength of recurrent PC synapses subject to local modulation (Fig. 6). This decoupling of spiking activity and synaptic efficacy suggests a mechanism by which V1 can amplify its output to downstream targets, such as higher visual areas, without generating excessive excitation in the local recurrent network. Such a mechanism could be important for maintaining the stability of computations that rely on balanced excitation and inhibition. The suppression of PC output within V1 may therefore reflect a form of gating that allows feedforward communication to be selectively boosted while shielding local circuits from saturation. This prediction of the model is in line with the known actions of acetylcholine on presynaptic M2 receptors, which reduce glutamate release at PC terminals16–18.

sec.title: Locomotion shapes cortical dynamics through multiple pathways
sec.p: The first effect of locomotion was to enhance a slow sensitizing signal activated by the visual stimulus, the major target of which was VIP interneurons (Fig. 4). The source of this signal is likely the cholinergic input from basal forebrain 2,13–15 and optogenetic experiments demonstrate that it determined the dynamics of adaption in SST (Fig. 4 and Supplementary Figure 1). The second major effect predicted by the model was a near 90% reduction in the strength of PC synapses across all targets (Fig. 6G), consistent with a range of evidence obtained in vitro demonstrating that M2 muscarinic receptor-cause presynaptic inhibition16,17,67. A similar mechanism likely operates at PV synapses, where release probability is reduced by M2 and M4 receptors55–57. However, the situation is different for SST interneurons. Our modelling shows that depressing PCs receive strong SST inputs at rest and that these synapses are potentiated during locomotion (Fig. 7E-G). This is likely to reflect a post-synaptic action of M1 receptors which have been shown to enhance postsynaptic GABAA currents in visual and somatosensory57,58. In contrast, SST inputs to sensitizing PCs appeared weaker during locomotion (Fig. 7F).

We suggest that SSTs contacting PCs are predominantly Martinotti cells because these have been shown to depress strongly46,60,61. Non-Martinotti cells generate more variable responses and may dominate the input to depressing PCs, which also receive stronger inhibition from sensitizing PVs9. Notably, differential cholinergic modulation of Martinotti and non-Martinotti SSTs has also been observed in mouse somato-sensory cortex during whisking59, although it may also be that other neuromodulatory systems contribute to these mixed effects, including noradrenaline, serotonin and dopamine2,11. The models might be refined by splitting SSTs into two separate populations once responses were measured separately in each68 but a more important issue is to test the predicted changes in synaptic strength. The best way to do this would be to make paired electrophysological recordings of identified SST→PC connections during state transitions, but direct measurements of changes in synaptic strength in the cortex of behaving mice are very difficult - most of the available evidence is inferred from circuit-level activity patterns and in vitro studies.

A key insight from our modelling is that the relative strength of PV and SST inputs predicts both the direction of PC adaptation and the degree of locomotion-induced gain modulation (Fig. 7). Depressing PCs receive stronger PV input, consistent with the rapid and temporally precise inhibition64. In contrast, sensitizing PCs receive relatively stronger SST input which slowly depress to drive sensitization9. These differences in PV:SST ratio also contribute to the changes in gain associated with locomotion: because SST→PC weights increase substantially during locomotion (Fig. 6), PCs already dominated by SST input exhibit the largest gain enhancement. It is well established that there are substantial variations in the inhibitory input patterns to PCs but it is unclear how far these reflect the development of specific wiring patterns as opposed to the variability that will arise from random connections35,69,70.

sec.title: Modulation of SST→PC synaptic strength during changes in brain state
sec.p: An intriguing prediction of our model is that SST→PC synapses onto depressing PCs strengthen selectively during locomotion (Fig. 7F). What mechanisms might underlie this effect? While direct evidence is lacking in V1, cholinergic modulation has been shown to facilitate GABA release from SST interneurons in somatosensory cortex58,59. In principle, this possibility might be tested by targeted recordings of identified SST→PC connections during state transitions.

Why would the cortex preferentially enhance sensitizing PCs during locomotion? One possibility is that these changes maintain responsiveness to low contrast and transient stimuli in a visual environment that has become more dynamic with a strong component of visual flow. By selectively enhancing PCs that resist rapid depression, the circuit may preserve sensitivity to behaviourally relevant stimuli53,71. From a computational perspective, the ability to differentially modulate adaptive subpopulations allows the cortex to tune its operating regime to changes in behaviour. These findings might also be interpreted in terms of broader theories of predictive coding and attention72: locomotion likely reflects an internal state of heightened predictive engagement with the environment and it may be that selective amplification of sensitizing PCs serves to enhance cortical representations of expected sensory features.

sec.title: Animal preparation and multiphoton imaging in vivo
sec.p: All experimental procedures in mice were conducted according to the UK Animals Scientific Procedures Act (1986). These were performed at University of Sussex under personal and project licenses granted by the Home Office following review by the Animal Welfare and Ethics Review Board.

Experiments were performed in adult mice (P90-P260) using experimental methods described in detail previously9. Results are reported from Results are reported from four VIP-Cre mice (VIP tm1(cre)Zjh/J Jackson #010908), fourteen SST-Cre (SST tm2.1(cre)Zjh/J, Jackson #013044), four SST-Flp (Sst tm3.1(flpo)Zjh; Jackson #028579) x VIP-Cre and ten PV-Cre (Pvalb tm1(cre)Arbr/J, Jackson #008069), from either sex. Mice were prepared for head-fixed multiphoton imaging through a surgical procedure in a stereotaxic frame under isoflurane anaesthesia. A titanium head plate was attached to the skull and a 3 mm craniotomy was drilled to expose the brain. We then expressed AAV1.CaMKII.GCaMP6f.WPRE.SV40 to image calcium activity in pyramidal cells and AAV9.CAG.Flex.GCaMP6f.WPRE.SV40 to image interneurons in Cre lines. To excite interneurons optogenetically we used rAAV9/Syn.Flex.ChrimsonR.tdTomato and to inhibit them we used AAV5.CBA.Flex.ArchT-tdToma- to.WPRE.SV40.

During imaging mice were free to run on a cylindrical treadmill placed under a two-photon microscope, with stimuli being presented on two monitors covering most of the visual field. Visual stimuli were sinusoidal gratings drifting upwards (100% contrast, 1 Hz, 10 s duration) generated using the Python library PsychoPy73. The standard experimental protocol consisted of ten presentations of the stimulus with a 20 s interstimulus interval. When testing optogenetic manipulations these 10 trials were interleaved with 10 additional trials paired with illumination from an amber LED. The intensity of this LED was adjusted to activity of PCs to similar levels in different experiments. Running speed was measured with a rotary encoder and recorded through the imaging software (Scanimage5; Vidrio Technologies). The two-photon microscope (Scientifica SP1) employed a 16x water immersion objective (0.8 NA; Nikon) and imaging was carried out at a depth of 150-300 μm below the surface of the brain.

Raw movies were registered and segmented into regions of interest (ROIs) using the Suite2P package running in MATLAB 2021a 74 and further analysed using custom-written code in Igor Pro 8 (Wavemetrics). Here we only analyse results from the first session in which the animal was exposed to the stimulus to avoid effects of habituation. Stimulus trials were only included for analysis if the mouse was running faster than 3 cm/s for more than 80% of the time. To calculate the response dynamics of PC, PV, SST and VIP populations we only included cells that were positively correlated with the stimulus. For each cell, the Pearson’s correlation coefficients was computed between its activity trace (ΔF/F) and a stimulus trace binarized as either stimulus off (0) or stimulus on (1) using the StatsLinearCorrelationTest Function in IgorPro (Wavemetrics). The threshold for significant positive or negative correlation was set at p < 0.05. Measurements of adaptive properties were confined to cells which were significantly positively correlated with the stimulus. The adaptive index (AI) was calculated from the GCaMP6f signal as AI = (R1 – R2)/(R1 + R2) where R1 is the average response over the period 0.5 - 2.5 s after stimulus onset and R2 is the average at 8-10 s.

sec.title: Estimation of firing rates
sec.p: To estimate firing rates from the recorded ΔF/F data we used the MLspike algorithm using initial parameters expected for GCaMP6f23. Briefly, this finds the optimal spike train to fit the calcium fluorescence trace (ΔF/F) taking into account estimates of baseline fluorescence level and neuronal parameters including the amplitude of the unitary Ca2+ transient generated by a spike (A) and the decay time-constant of that transient (τ). In general, we followed recommendations and demos in the article and on the MLspike GitHub page. We set the range for A to be between 1 and 50% and τ was set at values from 0.05 to 3 seconds. The parameter Amax, which corresponds to the maximum amplitude of detected events, was 9, and the saturation parameter was set to 0.002. The Hill coefficient for Ca2+ binding to GCaMP6f was varied in the range from 1 to 3.75 with step sizes of 0.25.

sec.title: Model of the circuit in layer 2/3 of V1
sec.p: We built a rate-based data-driven population model of the network circuit in the mouse visual cortex layer 2/3 (code and example data sets at https://github.com/lagnadoLab/CortexModel). The purpose of the model was to understand adaptive gain control during rest and locomoting states of four main neuron populations (PC, PV, SST, and VIP). The network was represented by the system of four mean-field first order ordinary differential equations (equation 1)28. The neuronal input-output function, f(x), was a rectified power law30 (6)f(x)=k([x]+threshold)n where k is a scaling coefficient which was set to 1. This is a rectified linear function with a lower threshold, [x]+threshold of zero to prevent negative values of firing rate and upper threshold of 25 to prevent run-away behaviour of the algorithm solving the network equations system. The exponent was set to n = 2 but a linear activation function (n = 1) produced similar results during the fitting process, as observed by others75.

Connectivity between and within populations is represented by total connection weight wji which is dependent on both the number of responsive cells in the presynaptic population and the strength of individual synapses. The number of presynaptic neurons responding to the stimulus varied between rest and locomotion so to assess changes in synaptic strength caused by neuromodulators the total connection weight was divided by the number of responsive presynaptic cells (Table 1 and equations 2 and 4 in Results). The aim of fitting the model to the average activity traces of each neuronal population was to obtain connection weights, w, wji Weights were set to zero where published work indicated that connections are very weak or non-existent, as between SST interneurons31,36. The final connection weights matrix for connections within layer 2/3 was represented as: (7)W=(wPC−PCwPC−PVwPC−SSTwPC−VIPwPV_PCwPV_PVwPV_SSTwPV_VIPwSST_PCwSST_PVwSST−SSTwSST_VIPwVIP_PCwVIP−PVwVIP−SSTwVIP−VIP)=(wPC−PCwPC−PVwPC−SSTwPC−VIPwPV_PCwPV_PV00wSST_PCwSST−PV0wSST−VIP00wVIP_SST0)

sec.title: External inputs driving activity
sec.p: Three types of external input drove activity in the circuit which we termed feedforward (FF), slow modulation (SM) and feedback input (FB): the forms and origins of these are discussed in Results. These were represented in Equation 1 by the variable In that was specific for each input. The FF input was defined by the following system of equations: (8)ln⁡FF(t)={0,(t<sstart+sdel)I0+Afe−(t−sstart−sdel)λf,(sstart+sdel+sk>t≥sstart+sdel)I0+Afe−(t−sstart−sdel)λf+k(t−sstart−sdel),(sstart+sdur≥t≥sstart+sdel+sk)(I0+Afe−(sdur−sdel)λf+k(sdur−sdel−sstart))e−(t−sstart−sdur)decayf,(t>sstart+sdur) The initial short fast-depressing component had an amplitude Af and decayed exponentially with a decay rate λf. The variables sstart, sdel, sdur, sk represent stimulus start, delay in the initiation of the response in a cell, the stimulus duration and an offset after the initial peak, respectively. This offset defined the initiation of a second slow increase in feedforward input that has been observed in response to drifting gratings lasting seconds22,42. At the end of the stimulus presentation, experimental traces decayed relatively slowly compared with the time-constant of the model neurons and this was accounted for by including an exponentially decaying component to the input with the argument decayf.

The temporal form of the feedforward input measured experimentally reflects the application of a spatio-temporal Gabor filter to a sinusoidal wave of drifting gratings76. This oscillation was clear in the activity of individual PCs but less evident in population averages because neurons responded with different phases, depending on the location of their receptive fields relative to the stimulus. This 1 Hz oscillation was most clearly observed in the average response of the SST population (Fig. 6C, bottom) which have larger receptive fields and therefore display less phase shifting46. We did not, therefore, attempt to model the oscillatory component of individual neuronal responses and concentrated on capturing the average activity across populations. The feedforward input (FF) was defined as a step of duration sdur with initial amplitude (l0 + Af) which then decayed to a steady state of l0 with time-constant 210 ms, defined by fitting the initial peak of the average PC response. The steady state was half the initial maximum with Af = l0. The linear increase is a simplified representation of the sensitizing behaviour observed experimentally in layer 4 activity22,42.

The slow modulatory input was represented by the following system of equations: (9)InSM(t)={0,(t<sstart)As1+e(sstart+del-t)λs,sstart+sdur≥t≥sstart,Ase−(t−sstart−sdur)decays1+e(del−sdur)λs,(t>sstart+sdur) where sstart, sdur represent the time of the stimulus start and the stimulus duration, respectively. The slow modulatory (SM) component is represented by a sigmoid function with an amplitude As, growth rate λs, and centre of sigmoid shifted to a del value from the stimulus starting time. Similarly to FF, the decay phase after the stimulus end was accounted for by the argument decays.

Finally, feedback input (FB) was represented by a step function: (10)InFB(t)={0,Afb,Afbe−(t−sstart−sdur)decayfb,(t<sstart+sfbdelay)∪​(t>sstart+sdur)(sstart+sdur≥t≥sstart+sfbdelay)(t>sstart+sdur) where sstart, sfb_delay, sdur represent time of the stimulus start, delay in the initiation of the response in a cell and the stimulus duration, respectively. The amplitude of the stimulus is defined by Afb. Similarly to FF and SM, the decay phase after stimulus end was accounted for by the argument decayfb. The amplitudes of Afb, As and Io were fixed around 1 Hz based on the average response of PCs during locomoting state (Fig. 2).

sec.title: Fitting the model
sec.p: To obtain values of connection weights we fit the model simultaneously to the average activity traces of the four neuronal populations using the LMFIT library in Python 77 by minimization of reduced chi-square parameter: (11)χreduced2=∑iN(datai−modeli)2stderri2(N−Nv), where (datai – modeli)/ stderri represents the residual function weighted by uncertainties in the experimental data, N is the number of data points and Nv is the number of variable parameters. We set the threshold chi-square value to be 15. We used standard errors of the mean (S.E.M) to weight locomotion data. For the data obtained from the resting state we used S.E.M = 1. Additionally, to have a measure of fit quality independent of the data uncertainty and number of varied parameters we calculated root mean square error (RMSE) for each fit: (12)RMSE=∑iN(datai−modeli)2N. We tested several fitting methods designed for a local minimum search: Levenberg-Marquardt, Nelder-Mead, Powell, L-BFGS-B and noticed that Nelder-Mead and Powell methods worked well on the full range of values defined by minimum and maximum limits of variable parameters, while the Levenberg-Marquardt and L-BFGS-B were better for final precise fitting.

Different sets of parameters sometimes provided similar values of reduced chi-square in multidimensional parameter space, indicating that networks with different connectivity parameters could produce similar activity patterns78, which in turn made the results sensitive to the initial guess of parameters. We set all weights to 0.5 as initial set of parameters for fitting. An important further constraint was provided by requiring the model to additionally fit the results of optogenetic manipulations of the PV and SST populations (Fig. 5), leading to a reduced number of sets of possible synaptic weights. In these experiments, the intensity of the LED was set to increase or decrease PV or SST activity by a known factor between 1.3 and 2, as measured empirically in other parallel experiments measuring GCaMP6f responses in these interneurons9. The average PV or SST activity trace was then scaled by the same factor for comparing the model to observed PC activity and RMSE value calculated for each comparison in optogenetic tests. This approach allowed us to find a stable set of parameters describing both the basic state of the circuit during locomotion and the effects of perturbing the circuit optogenetically. For fitting a resting state, we introduced initial conditions as a solution for the locomotion state and altered the initial values of weights that are known to be dependent on locomotion: external inputs to layer 2/3 are lower at rest, as is PC excitation to all populations12.

sec.title: Fitting the model to subpopulations of pyramidal cells
sec.p: The whole PC population was split into tertiles (sensitizers, intermediate cells and depressors) based on the distribution of adaptive index (Fig. 1). The average response of each subpopulation was then fit separately in the locomoting and resting states to assess changes in connectivity that describe the adaptive properties of each (Fig. 7). Three simplifying assumptions were made. First, that each subpopulation of PC receives the same shape of inputs as the average PC across the population. Second, only the synaptic weight of those connections directly targeting PCs were left free to vary while the other connections within the circuit were fixed. This was done because there is no change in activities of interneurons during separating a PC population into three subgroups and excitatory input from PCs to interneurons was taken as an average response of the whole PC population, similarly as during fitting of the whole network. Third, we used the initial conditions of the average models scaled to match amplitudes of subpopulations to average response. From Equations 1 and 6 the scaling factor is: (13)scale=wtertilewavg=AtertileAavg, where wi is a weight and Ai is an average amplitude of response during stimulus. Corresponding scaling multiplication factors for locomotion are: sensitizers = 1.1, intermediate = 1.2, depressors = 0.8, and for resting state are: sensitizers = 0.9, intermediate = 1.1, depressors = 0.9.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: For the statistical tests not directly related with the model fitting we used the analytical software Igor Pro 8 and/or SPSS (‘Statistical Package for the Social Sciences’, IBM). To determine if the mean of one group was significantly different from another group we used a t-test (two-sided) if the distribution was normally distributed or a non-parametric Mann–Whitney U test (MWU) if it was not. We used linear mixed modelling (LMM) to test for significant interaction between locomotion state and AI tertile (Fig. 1), because cells were not paired between locomotion and resting states. Locomotion state and AI tertile were defined as fixed variables and the animal ID was defined as the random variable. All averages are given as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM).
